Robin and Zoe are a father-daughter team and Carly is an honorary member of the family. All three of us have always been interested in all things spooky, and for many years Robin has also been a well-known tarot reader. A few months ago, the idea for Ace of Rods popped into our heads, and ever since then we have been striving to turn it into a reality that everyone can enjoy.
Ace of Rods is a story about James Castleton, an eccentric psychic, who one day is visited by a woman named Sally who claims to be his long-lost daughter. He lets her into his home, having no idea that she brings with her a storm of chaos and danger. 
We are writing ten ten-minute episodes that will lead you through this twisted tale of mischief and magic. It will be a unique experience for the viewer—think Breaking Bad meets Ghost—mixing comedy, suspense and the supernatural. With your help, we want to raise the money to shoot our pilot episode. We want our first episode to be a kick-ass introduction to our show, with a high production value that will maximize the entertainment for the viewer. There is no limit to what we can achieve with this, and the better our first episode is, the more chance we have of drawing the support that will help us bring the rest of our season to life.

What We Need & What You Get
We need $22,000. We have carefully compiled our budget so that we can pay everyone involved with Ace of Rods. This includes expenses for cast, crew, equipment, location, set design, costumes, catering, stunt coordination and editing.  
We want to set a high bar for our pilot in order to give Ace of Rods the best shot at becoming a full season of magic. We feel it’s important to pay a fair wage to everyone involved for their skills and talent. We have been economical where possible, but have given ourselves a higher budget in some areas (such as camera equipment) so that we aren’t making any artistic sacrifices.
You won’t regret helping us out! As well as getting to see our exciting final product, donors will be treated to a selection of very special perks. These include everything from a personalized message from the universe to our team hosting you and your friends to a delicious dinner followed by individual readings from our very own Robin Cleland.
Stretch Goals
As we said, we need $22,000 to shoot our pilot. However, with even more funding, the sky is the limit as to what we can achieve! Here’s a sneak peek at what we could do if your support takes us to the next level.
$30,000
For $30,000, we could not only shoot our pilot, but also hire someone to help us publicize it to the fullest, and launch a marketing campaign to reach the widest possible audience. Not only this, but we would have extra money to increase our spending on things like set dressing, costumes and special effects. Help us make the experience of Ace of Rods even more magical!
$60,000 
For $60,000, we could shoot our first three episodes. This would help us launch our show with a much bigger impact, and of course it would also provide even more entertainment for you, the viewer!
$200,000
For $200,000, we could shoot our entire first season. We would be able to give you ten episodes of Ace of Rods to binge on. Then you could follow James, Sally and Annie through all the twists and turns of their thrilling and hilarious adventures without having to press the pause button. Hang on for a wild ride!
Where will your money go if we don’t reach our goal?
We are going to make Ace of Rods happen no matter what! Even if we don’t reach our goal here on Indiegogo, we will continue crowdfunding until we raise the necessary funds. 
There are two worst-case scenarios.​ O​ne would be that we would have to delay production by a few months. The other would come into play if we are ​only able to raise $18,000.​ In this second case, we could still shoot our pilot,​ but it​ would mean using much lower-quality cameras and paying some of our team members a lot less than their time is worth. We want to avoid this​ at all costs! (N​o pun intended!​) 
Either way, we will keep all our backers informed of our shooting schedule and progress. Rest assured that any money you donate will go to the production of our spooky,​ funny and completely original web series—Ace of Rods.
What’s Our Track Record?
It comes down to this, why should you trust us with your money? As psychic as we are, not all aspects of the future can be divined completely! However, we can tell you what we have accomplished in the past, and you can decide for yourself. All of our core team members have extensive experience in the industry, with many different specialties between us.
Although much of his life has been devoted to his psychic work, Robin Cleland has made his mark in the acting world in a very short period of time. Most notably, he has appeared in acclaimed shows Taken and Alias Grace. Robin also single–handedly wrote, produced and starred in his original one-man show Don’t Look Down at the Berkeley Street Theatre in 2011.
Our co-director and director of photography, Trish Young, is an award-winning DP. After receiving the CSC Award For Best Cinematography in a student film category, she has been sponsored by numerous companies and has had the opportunity of working on a vast array of projects. She has boundless energy that she brings with her everywhere she goes!
Zoe Cleland is a classically trained actress who has been working in the industry for most of her life. She has been featured in many well-known shows, including Murdoch Mysteries, Reign, and Saving Hope, as well as the award-winning indie comedy How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town. Zoe also produced and starred in her own adaptation of Chekhov’s Uncle Vanya in a site-specific production in 2013.
Last but not least, Carly Sztern has had a particularly unique view of the industry. She recently appeared in Karla, a romantic comedy that premiered earlier this year. She has also entered the world of casting, where she has worked for Forrest & Forrest Casting as well as Larissa Mair Casting & Associates. 
Risks & Challenges
Ace of Rods is a passion project, so of course it comes with a unique set of challenges. We have a very clear artistic vision that has a lot of momentum behind it, but we need the financial backing to go hand-in-hand with the energy of our ideas.  We believe our show deserves the highest production quality we can possibly give it, and that means hiring the best team. In order to do that we need your support so that we can make the experience of working on Ace of Rods worth their while.
We believe in the strength of our story. We have landed on a very special idea and we are determined to make it a reality no matter what. Every single person involved in our project feels just as strongly as we do, and we feel confident that that kind of artistic passion will carry us through to our final goal.

The Impact
Ace of Rods will be a show that will surprise and delight the viewer. It will be unique in its combination of wildly imaginative and magical storylines right alongside topical themes of crime and corruption. Our bottom line is entertainment: we want to make a show that you can’t wait to binge on: a distraction from your day-to-day life that will give you a shot of adrenaline and make you laugh at the same time.
Please give today and help us bring the SPIRIT of our eerie show into the light!

Other Ways You Can Help
Please contribute to our campaign! We are grateful for all donations, big or small.
We do understand that not everyone is in a position to give money. If that’s the case for you, that’s ok! Anything you can do to help would be greatly appreciated. Please consider sharing our campaign, following us on social media, and of course watching Ace of Rods when it’s released. 
Thank you!

story:
CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE, WATCH, AND SHARE ON YOUTUBE! 

"LIKE" JOSH CLEMENT PRODUCTIONS LLC ON FACEBOOK!

"LIKE" ED KANZE, NATURALIST AND ADIRONDACK GUIDE, ON FACEBOOK!

The Adirondack Park in New York is a wondrous and unique place -- three times the size of Yellowstone and the largest park in the Lower 48. On the private lands in the park live about 100,000 year-round residents, all of them hardy and a great many quirky and ferociously independent. To live in the midst of the most extensive temperate deciduous forest on the planet, they endure long cold winters, swarms of biting insects, and a rugged, rocky, frost-haunted landscape that defies inhabitants of all species to eke out their livings.

It's a hard place to prosper. Yet for all the rocky patches, the people who dare to live inside the park are well rewarded by grand scenery, abundant wildlife, and no end of free entertainment in the form of skiing, skating, snowshoeing, hiking, boating, swimming, berry picking, fishing, hunting, and gardening (although it's not always easy to produce a ripe tomato here.)

The aim of our project is high. That is, to do this place and its singular people justice. We want to bring Adirondack Mountain life alive for all the poor souls who don't share the pleasure and pain of living here.

Josh Clement is a Renaissance man, not only a talented and richly creative videographer but also a musician, composer, husband, and father of two with a delightfully zany sense of humor. His company, Josh Clement Productions LLC, makes compelling, illuminating videos for a variety of clients. Ed Kanze has a Renaissance streak, too. A former National Park Ranger, he writes books, magazine stories, and newspaper columns, climbs trees, chases birds, shoots nature photos, travels the world, and when not behaving like Huck Finn or Crocodile Dundee, runs an Adirondack Mountain nature guiding service. He is the father of two, too.

Clement & Kanze have produced three seasons of Curiously Adirondack together, plus a straightforward science piece on earthworms, a Monty Pythonesque piece on blackflies with highbrow allusions to Orson Welles and Joseph Conrad, and a video about the latest archeological work in the Adirondacks, archeology that is rewriting the standard story of American Indians in these mountains.

Want to be a movie producer? Producers round up the dollars that make movies happen. No dollars, no movies. No producers, no dollars. So join us, please! Make a contribution, small, medium, or large to Curiously Adirondack's exciting new fourth season and add your name to our team of producers!

Our Indigogo campaign goal is to raise $85,000. This will complement a parallel effort to secure major donors.

We're not going to fatten our wallets making these videos. We're going to work long and diligently, for modest rewards. Weeks of professional work---developing ideas, making contacts, arranging shoots, shooting video, shooting stills, recording sound, sifting through hours of material, finding a story line that's compelling and adds up to something, writing, editing, more editing, even more editing, recording voice-overs, adding music, tweaking, polishing, posting, and more--- go into producing a few minutes of polished final product.

We aim to do our unique subjects justice. And we can't do it without you. Please, make a contribution and help Curiously Adirondack - Season Four rocket into the stratosphere!

The videos supported by this campaign will entertain, encourage, inform, inspire laughs, and generally make the world, and the Adirondack Mountain region in particular, a better, kinder place, one short increment (five to ten minutes) at a time. 

Curiously Adirondack - Season Four episodes will likely include:

  • A visit with a craftsman who makes beautiful rustic furniture out of tree trunks
  • A look at the vibrant, popular, but little known Adirondack rock-and-roll scene
  • Small-town politics through the eyes of a small-town politician (We have one in mind but he doesn't know it yet.)
  • Paddling in canoes or kayaks in the Adirondacks but (as the saying goes) out of this world
  • The wild and woolly world of wildlife research, in which we tag along with biologists in the field
  • Who says Indians didn't inhabit the Adirondacks? A visit with Mohawk people whose ancestors may go back here 12,000 years
  • The evolution of Saranac Lake's Community store
  • Way down South in Northville: the gem of a village on Great Sacandaga Lake

Raising money isn't easy. We can all use more of it. We're going to work hard to carry out this campaign, pleading, cajoling, and doling out incentives. If we succeed, our work will only be beginning. It's not simple making videos in the Adirondacks. You have to face blackflies, mosquitoes, no-see-ums, deer-flies, the occasional lovesick moose and hungry bear, along with inquisitive tourists and locals who have good reason to wonder what you're doing behind and in front of that camera. Conditions like these breed tenacity. We never surrender. And so, the Clement-Kanze Curiously Adirondack production team will work hard and long. We expect to march forward until, with your help, victory is achieved.

Phase two has already been touched upon. It involves hard work behind and in front of the camera, writing, rewriting, recording voice-overs, and long hours in the production room cutting, splicing, adding, subtracting, plugging in sound effects and video flourishes, and then getting the final product up on the web for you to view and enjoy.

If we fail to reach our goal (you won't let that happen, but in the unlikely case that the pawn shop denies fair value for your treasures or the pennies in a jar on your kitchen counter add up to less than expected), we’ll produce an abbreviated season.

If disposable income is short or otherwise indisposed, please contribute to Curiously Adirondack in other ways. Blab about us on Facebook. Effuse on LinkedIn. Yak on Twitter. Send to your friends and Gram on Instagram. Tell your friends, your auto mechanic, your hairdresser, and the mailman. Be creative on behalf of creativity. We can use all the help we can get. By golly, we'll be greatly grateful for it.

The more people know about Curiously Adirondack, the more they'll rummage dresser drawers for spare coins and push us toward our goal. Please spread the word!

Thanks for listening. Thanks for watching. Thanks for supporting Curiously Adirondack!

By design, Curiously Adirondack belongs to the world. Anyone with access to the Internet can watch and share Season 1-3 on YouTube and the official Mountain Lake PBS Facebook page. Numerous bonus video clips and photos can be found on the official Josh Clement Productions Facebook and Ed Kanze, Naturalist and Adirondack Guide Facebook pages, Instagram and Twitter. All this is to say: we're connected! The beauty of Curiously Adirondack is that once a season is funded, it's a free-for-all! Share your favorite episodes with friends and neighbors. Use the commenting features to start a conversation. We love that!

Citizen supporters of the series can be proud knowing that our work exists because of them. Business sponsors can reap the rewards of seeing their branding on our videos indefinitely. That's right! Once you sponsor a season you're there for the long haul. These videos and the sponsor credits that go with them may outlast all of us. What other form of advertising can make that claim? Check out past business sponsors at the end of each video.

Thank you to all the individuals and business sponsors who have supporters the last three seasons of Curiously Adirondack. And to all of our followers, old and new, enjoy this look back at the entire body of work. With your help, more will be on the way. Cheers!   

Lady Of The Locks: DEC Lock Tender Margaret Hawthorn Lifts And Lowers Boats Along The Saranac River

Boats go up, and boats go down: canoes, kayaks, fishing boats, and more, traveling the watery channel through the woods rising between the Lower and Middle Saranac Lakes. It all flows smoothly, largely thanks to the hard work of lock tender Margaret Hawthorn. The Upper Locks operate the old-fashioned way, with muscle and finesse. Margaret loves the job and does it with a skill and passion that make a passage through the Upper Locks an experience long remembered. Learn more about the New York State Department of Conservation (DEC) by visiting www.dec.ny.gov.

A Walker Among Boats: DEC Lock Tender Scott Walker Lifts And Lowers Boats Along The Saranac River

To pass up and down the watery channels connecting the Adirondack village of Saranac Lake with the Lower and Middle Saranac Lakes, boats as small as canoes and kayaks (as well as recreational watercraft larger and speedier) pass through the Lower and Upper Locks. Curiously Adirondack visits Scott Walker, the hard-working and eloquent keeper of the Lower Locks, Walker shares his remote workplace and the singular and important duties he performs. Learn more about the New York State Department of Conservation (DEC) by visiting www.dec.ny.gov.

They Prowl By Night: Seeking The Wild Adirondack Bullhead

For many in the Adirondacks, the bullhead was the original fish, the one that gave the first sweet taste of fishing and its gastronomic and spiritual rewards. The bullhead is a fish to be admired, not only for its tender flesh, but also for its industrious nest-building and the devotion of both parents to the young. Hook one, and you may be hooked for life.

Ampersand Mountain, Queen Of The Saranac Lake Six

Ampersand Mountain in the Adirondacks is hardly a bump on the landscape compared to the great mountains of the West. Even by Adirondack standards, it's barely more than humble. Yet its rewards are as good as they get: diverse old woods rich in birds and wildflowers, and after a steep climb, one that will give you a week's cardiovascular exercise in an hour or two, a view that ranks among the finest in the East. Learn about The Saranac Lake 6er Hiking Challenge by visiting www.saranaclake6er.com.

C'est Magnifique! Avalanche Pass Lifts The Spirits As Well As Any Summit

To get there and back requires a ten-mile hike, beginning and ending at Adirondack Loj, near Lake Placid. Yet the rewards gained are as impressive as those delivered by any of the region's celebrated summits. This is a valley bottom that soars high on the Adirondack hiker's bucket list. Get the low-down! See what's up in spectacular Avalanche Pass. Learn more about Adirondack Loj and the work of the Adirondack Mountain Club by visiting www.adk.org.

You Can Get Anything You Want: On Schroon Lake, A Classic American General Store Still Thrives

Building on a history stretching back more than 150 years, the Adirondack General Store flourishes in the twenty-first century by offering the best of the old and the new. Proprietors Maureen and Robert Diaz made a bold move from Queens to the remote hamlet of Adirondack to buy and run the place. They sell everything from fishing poles to corn flakes and microbrew for grown-ups to retro candy for the kids. If you're hungry, they'll even serve you a home-cooked meal. This is the kind of place you pop in to grab a jar of pickles, and you wind up spending half a day browsing the aisles, chewing the fat with neighbors by the woodstove, meeting travelers, and reveling in the fine food and the old-time hardwood interior. Learn more at www.adkgeneralstore.com.

Canvas, Pain, And Wood: How Artist Paul Masson Brings Nature Alive In His Art

At the end of World War II, Paul Casson was given advice by friends: to soothe frazzled nerves he should take up painting. More than seventy years later, he's still at it, finding joy and serenity in capturing the beauty of nature with brush and oil. He carves and paints, birds, too, his work combining the delicate aesthetic sensibilities of an artist with the sturdy know-how of a naturalist and hunter.

Going "Ollywood": How A Modern Adirondack Sawmill Produces Old-Time Forest Products

A scientist turned sawyer named Ollie Burgess turns trees into rustic building materials in the northern Adirondack township of St. Armand. It's a bustling business. On one hand the yard and buildings at Specialty Wood Products appear straight out of the nineteenth century. On the other, Ollie and his team incorporate modern technology at every turn. Whether it's rough-sawn native lumber or a mortise-and-tenon-jointed cedar railing, if it's on a delivery truck bound for a building site in the United States, there's a good chance it's "Ollywood." Learn more at www.specialtywoodproductsadk.com.

Golly, Wally: Giant Beavers Still Surviving In The Adirondacks

For years, skeptics laughed and groaned while sightings and signs of an enormous aquatic rodent in the Adirondacks multiplied. Those who believe in the creature have come to agree that it's a giant beaver, Castoroides ohioensis, believed extinct for 11,000 years or more. If evidence pointing toward its presence can stand up to scrutiny, the black-bear-sized giant beaver may be making a comeback. Or not. It's your call!

For Whom The "Bel" Tolls: Saranac Lake's Belvedere Restaurant Keep Patrons Coming Back

Satisfying appetites and quenching thirsts since 1933, the Belvedere Restaurant throbs with activity in the heart of the Adirondack village of Saranac Lake. The Cavallo family founded the business. Eighty-five years later, they still run it proudly. With offerings ranging from Italian dishes made from old family recipes to the latest high-hopped microbrews, the "Bel," as loyal patrons call it, offers a delicious escape from the mad, mad world. Here the raging river of time slows to a sane pace, and the chicken parmigiana is always as warm as the welcome. Give The Belvedere a "LIKE" on Facebook.

The Fabric Of Friendship: Old Forge's Pointed Pine Quilters Join Hearts, Hands, And Fabric

In Old Forge, on the Adirondack Mountains' wild and beautiful western side, the Pointed Pine Quilters have been getting together to make magic from fabric---and thread---since the midpoint of the twentieth century. Today's group meets weekly at the Old Forge Public Library. Upstairs in a room devoted to their art and craft, the quilters enjoy the pleasures of friendship while piecing and stitching to raise funds for charity.

Woods, Rocks, And A View To Live For: Saint Regis Mountain In The Adirondacks

Tucked here and there among the celebrated Adirondack forty-six high peaks, lesser mountains offer hikers bigger bangs for the energy required to climb them. The best of the least may well be St. Regis Mountain. Located near Paul Smith's, this 2,874-foot knob of ancient bedrock rewards hikers with magnificent views and a walk through woods rich in beauty and interest. Learn more about the historic Saint Regis Mountain Fire Tower by visiting www.friendsofstregis.org. Check out The Saranac Lake 6er Hiking Challenge by visiting www.saranaclake6er.com. 

All Roads Lead To Bloomingdale: 19th Century Crossroads Village Blooms Anew In The 21st Century

If Thornton Wilder had looked a little further west, he might have set his Pulitzer Prize-winning play "Our Town" not in Grover's Corners, New Hampshire but in the Adirondack Mountain village of Bloomingdale. In the 1840s, the banks of Sumner Brook, a humble tributary of the Saranac, gave rise to a settlement that flourishes---quietly and soulfully, in the vein of "Our Town"---to this day. Bloomingdale has had its ups and downs. Yet from the playground and ballfield behind the fire house to its once-grand Main Street and two placid cemeteries, this is a place where people live, love, raise families, grow old, and return to the Earth with dignity, sustained through it all by a devotion to home and neighbors.

A Whole Lotta Flutterin' Goin' On: Butterflies Fly At The Paul Smith's VIC Butterfly House

Out in the Adirondack wilds, we see plenty of butterflies: one here, one there, and on sunny days sometimes just about everywhere. To learn about their lives and lore, and to see a variety up close, there's no better idea than to visit the Butterfly House. It's in Paul Smith's, at the Visitor Interpretive Center run by Paul Smith's College, right next door. Prepare to be amazed!  

A Taste Of Oak: Adirondack Coopers Bring Flavor To Regional Whiskey

Along a country road and down a long gravel driveway, Adirondack coopers Bob Hockert and Justin Bidelspach make world-class barrels fit for aging fine whiskies. They begin with select white oak boards cut by sawyers to their specifications. In the end, after much shaving, joining, charring, assembling, and the pressing on of hoops, a barrel is born---handsome, shapely, supremely practical, and prized by a rapidly expanding array of regional distillers. Learn more by visiting www.usbarrel.com.

Kids As Pets: Why Your Next 'Dog' Might Be A Goat

In the Adirondacks, people love their pets. Some of them---the pets, that is---weigh two hundred pounds or more and thrive on pine needles, poison-ivy, and other delicacies you can't buy at the supermarket. Ask these animals to sit up like trained dogs, and they'll say Naaaaaaaaaaaa. Yes, goats! For many of us, they are the pet of choice, and some earn livings or parts of livings raising and milking them, too. Learn more about Asgaard Farm & Dairy by visiting www.asgaardfarm.com.

The Adirondack Mountain Village Of Saranac Lake Remembers Its Curative Past

Most of us have heard William Faulkner's famous line about the past not being dead. His wisdom is nowhere more apparent than in the Adirondack Mountain village of Saranac Lake. Here, from the 1880s to the 1950s and a little bit beyond, tuberculosis patients arrived from near and far to rest on porches, breathe crisp pine-scented mountain air, and get well or die trying. Antibiotic therapy eventually put the village's sanitariums and cure cottages out of business. Still, in architecture, memory, story, and a heart-breaking poem penned by a brilliant young woman who didn't live to see it published, the village's rich past remains alive. Learn more about the work of Historic Saranac Lake by visiting www.historicsaranaclake.org.

Catch Our Drift: Why Adirondackers Love Winter, Sort Of

Do we in the Adirondacks love snow and cold? Do we hate them? Hear dyed-in-the-wool locals speak their minds about our long, cold, crystalline season.

Fifty Beds, Two Lakes, And An Otter: Bartlett's Hotel In Its Heyday, 1854-1884

The late nineteenth century might be called the Golden Age of Adirondack Hotels. Among the humble and the grand, one establishment stands out above all the others for its character and for its characters: Virgil and Caroline Bartlett's Sportsmen's Home, which had its heyday from 1854 to 1884. "Bartlett's," as the place was often called, stood at the downstream end of the Bartlett Carry between the Upper and Middle Saranac Lakes. Fran Yardley, a professional storyteller and author, has lived near the remote site of the hotel for more than forty years. She's our guide as Curiously Adirondack takes a look at a place renowned for its warm welcomes, delicious meals, cozy rooms, and pet otter. Be sure to watch for Fran's upcoming book FINDING TRUE NORTH: A History of One Small Corner of the Adirondacks releasing July 1, 2018. Sign up for her monthly newsletter by clicking here.     

Adirondack Exercise Club

Hardy Adirondack Mountain folk chant 1-2-3-4 as we prepare to stay warm during cold, snowy winters that can last half the year or more. It's all about firewood: felling it, sawing it to length, hauling it out of the woods, splitting it, moving it, stacking it, moving it again a time or two, and finally feeding it to hungry woodstoves. Yes, an unlucky few of us twirl thermostats, summon central heat, and hand over hard-earned cash to the oil and gas industry, but the rest of us maintain our trim figures, keep strong, and get free cardiovascular exercise as we work out at the most popular exercise club in the region.

Intervale Lowlands: Biologist Larry Master Re-Wilds 135 Acres Near Lake Placid

In 2009, biologist Larry Master and his then-wife, Nancy, bought 135 acres of woods, fields, flowing water, and floodplain near Lake Placid in the Adirondack Mountains. Their mission: to make the property sing with songbirds, to convert its mowed fields to meadows full of native plants and animals, and to identify and monitor its wildlife in an era of rapid climate change. They decided to call the place, tucked in an exquisite river valley between ranges of mountains, Intervale Lowlands.

What Does The Moose Say?

There are spelling bees. There are trivia contests. There are athletic games and lumberjack competitions. But have you ever seen and heard a moose-calling contest? The scene is wild, competitors are fierce, and it's all in good fun. Learn more about the Great Adirondack Moose Festival by visiting www.indian-lake.com.

Dirt, Food, And Friends: Fledging Crow Farm Celebrates The Harvest

In Keeseville, on the eastern edge of upstate New York's Adirondack Mountains, a new-fangled subscription farm called Fledging Crow grows food the old fashioned way: with lots of elbow grease, lots of help from neighbors, and no artificial fertilizers or pesticides. Every year, the farmers celebrate their harvest and the community of life that made it possible by throwing a giant party, a sort of mini-Woodstock in the fields. It's called CrowFest. Join Curiously Adirondack as we mix and mingle with a curious cast of characters who tell the story of Fledging Crow Farm and who and what make it work.

Asleep Beneath The Sod: Saranac Lake's Historic Pine Ridge Cemetery

Saranac Lake's Pine Ridge Cemetery sprawls over a sandy hillside in the heart of the village. In it lie the last remains of the village's first settlers, and keeping them company are hundreds of others, some well known and some not, who followed them across the great divide. Join Curiously Adirondack in a ramble through the cemetery with the best of all possible guides: Natalie Leduc, one of the village's grand dames, a former Winter Carnival queen who looks after the cemetery and, when her rich and adventurous life is done, aims to be buried there.

Slimed! Adirondack Kids Love Amphibians

Adirondack kids can't resist slimy things that hop and crawl. Join three warm-blooded young naturalists as they hunt for frogs, toads, and salamanders. Don't think amphibians are cool? Maybe we can change your mind.

If you made it this far, perhaps you're interested. Great! And thank you.

Fundraising is tricky business. Let's be honest. Who enjoys asking for money? Still, ask we must--- because we believe in the value of Curiously Adirondack. Judging by the positive feedback we've received over the years, we know our storytelling resonates. So we hope you'll join us and find that supporting Curiously Adirondack is a little less painful than paying your monthly cable bill. Hundreds of channel choices are great. Yet not one of those channels highlights the Adirondacks like we do.

We're proud that our supporters always know where their money is going. We're just a couple of family guys trying to make a living, doing what we do best. Support of any sort means the world to us. Thank you!

When my wife Holly and I launched Josh Clement Productions two and a half years ago we did so with two goals in mind: to tell human-interest stories that focus on those who live, work, and play in the Adirondacks and to use the business and production skills we've gathered over the years to earn a dollar. Although not without its challenges, we've managed to thrive.

We've helped numerous institutions, organizations, and businesses reach video and web marketing goals. For that we are proud. Yet for us, all roads lead back to Curiously Adirondack. The series has generated excitement. The numbers are there to prove it. People ask, "When can we see the next episode of Curiously Adirondack?" Or they’ll say, "I've got the perfect story idea for you guys. It would make a great Curiously Adirondack!" I love that! The enthusiasm leaves me smiling . I know we're onto something special.

Which leads to the main point I wanted to make. Why does Curiously Adirondack work? Why is it essential to the success of Josh Clement Productions? The answer leads to my collaborator, my friend and neighbor, Ed Kanze. Putting together Curiously Adirondack is hard work. I could not do it alone. One needs only to look at the credits of any quality video production to realize what makes them shine. Ed Kanze is a seasoned storyteller, author, photographer, editor, and more. He is quick to praise what I bring to the table. For that I am most appreciative. Well, it goes both ways. I’m thrilled to be in his corner.

Ed and I will remain forever Curiously Adirondack! How about you?
story_txt:
CLICK HERE TO SUBSCRIBE, WATCH, AND SHARE ON YOUTUBE! "LIKE" JOSH CLEMENT PRODUCTIONS LLC ON FACEBOOK!"LIKE" ED KANZE, NATURALIST AND ADIRONDACK GUIDE, ON FACEBOOK!The Adirondack Park in New York is a wondrous and unique place -- three times the size of Yellowstone and the largest park in the Lower 48. On the private lands in the park live about 100,000 year-round residents, all of them hardy and a great many quirky and ferociously independent. To live in the midst of the most extensive temperate deciduous forest on the planet, they endure long cold winters, swarms of biting insects, and a rugged, rocky, frost-haunted landscape that defies inhabitants of all species to eke out their livings.It's a hard place to prosper. Yet for all the rocky patches, the people who dare to live inside the park are well rewarded by grand scenery, abundant wildlife, and no end of free entertainment in the form of skiing, skating, snowshoeing, hiking, boating, swimming, berry picking, fishing, hunting, and gardening (although it's not always easy to produce a ripe tomato here.)The aim of our project is high. That is, to do this place and its singular people justice. We want to bring Adirondack Mountain life alive for all the poor souls who don't share the pleasure and pain of living here.Josh Clement is a Renaissance man, not only a talented and richly creative videographer but also a musician, composer, husband, and father of two with a delightfully zany sense of humor. His company, Josh Clement Productions LLC, makes compelling, illuminating videos for a variety of clients. Ed Kanze has a Renaissance streak, too. A former National Park Ranger, he writes books, magazine stories, and newspaper columns, climbs trees, chases birds, shoots nature photos, travels the world, and when not behaving like Huck Finn or Crocodile Dundee, runs an Adirondack Mountain nature guiding service. He is the father of two, too.Clement & Kanze have produced three seasons of Curiously Adirondack together, plus a straightforward science piece on earthworms, a Monty Pythonesque piece on blackflies with highbrow allusions to Orson Welles and Joseph Conrad, and a video about the latest archeological work in the Adirondacks, archeology that is rewriting the standard story of American Indians in these mountains.Want to be a movie producer? Producers round up the dollars that make movies happen. No dollars, no movies. No producers, no dollars. So join us, please! Make a contribution, small, medium, or large to Curiously Adirondack's exciting new fourth season and add your name to our team of producers!Our Indigogo campaign goal is to raise $85,000. This will complement a parallel effort to secure major donors.We're not going to fatten our wallets making these videos. We're going to work long and diligently, for modest rewards. Weeks of professional work---developing ideas, making contacts, arranging shoots, shooting video, shooting stills, recording sound, sifting through hours of material, finding a story line that's compelling and adds up to something, writing, editing, more editing, even more editing, recording voice-overs, adding music, tweaking, polishing, posting, and more--- go into producing a few minutes of polished final product.We aim to do our unique subjects justice. And we can't do it without you. Please, make a contribution and help Curiously Adirondack - Season Four rocket into the stratosphere!The videos supported by this campaign will entertain, encourage, inform, inspire laughs, and generally make the world, and the Adirondack Mountain region in particular, a better, kinder place, one short increment (five to ten minutes) at a time. Curiously Adirondack - Season Four episodes will likely include:
A visit with a craftsman who makes beautiful rustic furniture out of tree trunks
A look at the vibrant, popular, but little known Adirondack rock-and-roll scene
Small-town politics through the eyes of a small-town politician (We have one in mind but he doesn't know it yet.)
Paddling in canoes or kayaks in the Adirondacks but (as the saying goes) out of this world
The wild and woolly world of wildlife research, in which we tag along with biologists in the field
Who says Indians didn't inhabit the Adirondacks? A visit with Mohawk people whose ancestors may go back here 12,000 years
The evolution of Saranac Lake's Community store
Way down South in Northville: the gem of a village on Great Sacandaga Lake
Raising money isn't easy. We can all use more of it. We're going to work hard to carry out this campaign, pleading, cajoling, and doling out incentives. If we succeed, our work will only be beginning. It's not simple making videos in the Adirondacks. You have to face blackflies, mosquitoes, no-see-ums, deer-flies, the occasional lovesick moose and hungry bear, along with inquisitive tourists and locals who have good reason to wonder what you're doing behind and in front of that camera. Conditions like these breed tenacity. We never surrender. And so, the Clement-Kanze Curiously Adirondack production team will work hard and long. We expect to march forward until, with your help, victory is achieved.Phase two has already been touched upon. It involves hard work behind and in front of the camera, writing, rewriting, recording voice-overs, and long hours in the production room cutting, splicing, adding, subtracting, plugging in sound effects and video flourishes, and then getting the final product up on the web for you to view and enjoy.If we fail to reach our goal (you won't let that happen, but in the unlikely case that the pawn shop denies fair value for your treasures or the pennies in a jar on your kitchen counter add up to less than expected), we’ll produce an abbreviated season.If disposable income is short or otherwise indisposed, please contribute to Curiously Adirondack in other ways. Blab about us on Facebook. Effuse on LinkedIn. Yak on Twitter. Send to your friends and Gram on Instagram. Tell your friends, your auto mechanic, your hairdresser, and the mailman. Be creative on behalf of creativity. We can use all the help we can get. By golly, we'll be greatly grateful for it.The more people know about Curiously Adirondack, the more they'll rummage dresser drawers for spare coins and push us toward our goal. Please spread the word!Thanks for listening. Thanks for watching. Thanks for supporting Curiously Adirondack!By design, Curiously Adirondack belongs to the world. Anyone with access to the Internet can watch and share Season 1-3 on YouTube and the official Mountain Lake PBS Facebook page. Numerous bonus video clips and photos can be found on the official Josh Clement Productions Facebook and Ed Kanze, Naturalist and Adirondack Guide Facebook pages, Instagram and Twitter. All this is to say: we're connected! The beauty of Curiously Adirondack is that once a season is funded, it's a free-for-all! Share your favorite episodes with friends and neighbors. Use the commenting features to start a conversation. We love that!Citizen supporters of the series can be proud knowing that our work exists because of them. Business sponsors can reap the rewards of seeing their branding on our videos indefinitely. That's right! Once you sponsor a season you're there for the long haul. These videos and the sponsor credits that go with them may outlast all of us. What other form of advertising can make that claim? Check out past business sponsors at the end of each video.Thank you to all the individuals and business sponsors who have supporters the last three seasons of Curiously Adirondack. And to all of our followers, old and new, enjoy this look back at the entire body of work. With your help, more will be on the way. Cheers!   Lady Of The Locks: DEC Lock Tender Margaret Hawthorn Lifts And Lowers Boats Along The Saranac RiverBoats go up, and boats go down: canoes, kayaks, fishing boats, and more, traveling the watery channel through the woods rising between the Lower and Middle Saranac Lakes. It all flows smoothly, largely thanks to the hard work of lock tender Margaret Hawthorn. The Upper Locks operate the old-fashioned way, with muscle and finesse. Margaret loves the job and does it with a skill and passion that make a passage through the Upper Locks an experience long remembered. Learn more about the New York State Department of Conservation (DEC) by visiting www.dec.ny.gov.
A Walker Among Boats: DEC Lock Tender Scott Walker Lifts And Lowers Boats Along The Saranac River

To pass up and down the watery channels connecting the Adirondack village of Saranac Lake with the Lower and Middle Saranac Lakes, boats as small as canoes and kayaks (as well as recreational watercraft larger and speedier) pass through the Lower and Upper Locks. Curiously Adirondack visits Scott Walker, the hard-working and eloquent keeper of the Lower Locks, Walker shares his remote workplace and the singular and important duties he performs. Learn more about the New York State Department of Conservation (DEC) by visiting www.dec.ny.gov.
They Prowl By Night: Seeking The Wild Adirondack Bullhead

For many in the Adirondacks, the bullhead was the original fish, the one that gave the first sweet taste of fishing and its gastronomic and spiritual rewards. The bullhead is a fish to be admired, not only for its tender flesh, but also for its industrious nest-building and the devotion of both parents to the young. Hook one, and you may be hooked for life.
Ampersand Mountain, Queen Of The Saranac Lake Six

Ampersand Mountain in the Adirondacks is hardly a bump on the landscape compared to the great mountains of the West. Even by Adirondack standards, it's barely more than humble. Yet its rewards are as good as they get: diverse old woods rich in birds and wildflowers, and after a steep climb, one that will give you a week's cardiovascular exercise in an hour or two, a view that ranks among the finest in the East. Learn about The Saranac Lake 6er Hiking Challenge by visiting www.saranaclake6er.com.
C'est Magnifique! Avalanche Pass Lifts The Spirits As Well As Any Summit

To get there and back requires a ten-mile hike, beginning and ending at Adirondack Loj, near Lake Placid. Yet the rewards gained are as impressive as those delivered by any of the region's celebrated summits. This is a valley bottom that soars high on the Adirondack hiker's bucket list. Get the low-down! See what's up in spectacular Avalanche Pass. Learn more about Adirondack Loj and the work of the Adirondack Mountain Club by visiting www.adk.org.
You Can Get Anything You Want: On Schroon Lake, A Classic American General Store Still Thrives

Building on a history stretching back more than 150 years, the Adirondack General Store flourishes in the twenty-first century by offering the best of the old and the new. Proprietors Maureen and Robert Diaz made a bold move from Queens to the remote hamlet of Adirondack to buy and run the place. They sell everything from fishing poles to corn flakes and microbrew for grown-ups to retro candy for the kids. If you're hungry, they'll even serve you a home-cooked meal. This is the kind of place you pop in to grab a jar of pickles, and you wind up spending half a day browsing the aisles, chewing the fat with neighbors by the woodstove, meeting travelers, and reveling in the fine food and the old-time hardwood interior. Learn more at www.adkgeneralstore.com.
Canvas, Pain, And Wood: How Artist Paul Masson Brings Nature Alive In His Art

At the end of World War II, Paul Casson was given advice by friends: to soothe frazzled nerves he should take up painting. More than seventy years later, he's still at it, finding joy and serenity in capturing the beauty of nature with brush and oil. He carves and paints, birds, too, his work combining the delicate aesthetic sensibilities of an artist with the sturdy know-how of a naturalist and hunter.
Going "Ollywood": How A Modern Adirondack Sawmill Produces Old-Time Forest Products

A scientist turned sawyer named Ollie Burgess turns trees into rustic building materials in the northern Adirondack township of St. Armand. It's a bustling business. On one hand the yard and buildings at Specialty Wood Products appear straight out of the nineteenth century. On the other, Ollie and his team incorporate modern technology at every turn. Whether it's rough-sawn native lumber or a mortise-and-tenon-jointed cedar railing, if it's on a delivery truck bound for a building site in the United States, there's a good chance it's "Ollywood." Learn more at www.specialtywoodproductsadk.com.

Golly, Wally: Giant Beavers Still Surviving In The Adirondacks

For years, skeptics laughed and groaned while sightings and signs of an enormous aquatic rodent in the Adirondacks multiplied. Those who believe in the creature have come to agree that it's a giant beaver, Castoroides ohioensis, believed extinct for 11,000 years or more. If evidence pointing toward its presence can stand up to scrutiny, the black-bear-sized giant beaver may be making a comeback. Or not. It's your call!
For Whom The "Bel" Tolls: Saranac Lake's Belvedere Restaurant Keep Patrons Coming Back

Satisfying appetites and quenching thirsts since 1933, the Belvedere Restaurant throbs with activity in the heart of the Adirondack village of Saranac Lake. The Cavallo family founded the business. Eighty-five years later, they still run it proudly. With offerings ranging from Italian dishes made from old family recipes to the latest high-hopped microbrews, the "Bel," as loyal patrons call it, offers a delicious escape from the mad, mad world. Here the raging river of time slows to a sane pace, and the chicken parmigiana is always as warm as the welcome. Give The Belvedere a "LIKE" on Facebook.
The Fabric Of Friendship: Old Forge's Pointed Pine Quilters Join Hearts, Hands, And Fabric

In Old Forge, on the Adirondack Mountains' wild and beautiful western side, the Pointed Pine Quilters have been getting together to make magic from fabric---and thread---since the midpoint of the twentieth century. Today's group meets weekly at the Old Forge Public Library. Upstairs in a room devoted to their art and craft, the quilters enjoy the pleasures of friendship while piecing and stitching to raise funds for charity.
Woods, Rocks, And A View To Live For: Saint Regis Mountain In The Adirondacks

Tucked here and there among the celebrated Adirondack forty-six high peaks, lesser mountains offer hikers bigger bangs for the energy required to climb them. The best of the least may well be St. Regis Mountain. Located near Paul Smith's, this 2,874-foot knob of ancient bedrock rewards hikers with magnificent views and a walk through woods rich in beauty and interest. Learn more about the historic Saint Regis Mountain Fire Tower by visiting www.friendsofstregis.org. Check out The Saranac Lake 6er Hiking Challenge by visiting www.saranaclake6er.com. 
All Roads Lead To Bloomingdale: 19th Century Crossroads Village Blooms Anew In The 21st Century

If Thornton Wilder had looked a little further west, he might have set his Pulitzer Prize-winning play "Our Town" not in Grover's Corners, New Hampshire but in the Adirondack Mountain village of Bloomingdale. In the 1840s, the banks of Sumner Brook, a humble tributary of the Saranac, gave rise to a settlement that flourishes---quietly and soulfully, in the vein of "Our Town"---to this day. Bloomingdale has had its ups and downs. Yet from the playground and ballfield behind the fire house to its once-grand Main Street and two placid cemeteries, this is a place where people live, love, raise families, grow old, and return to the Earth with dignity, sustained through it all by a devotion to home and neighbors.
A Whole Lotta Flutterin' Goin' On: Butterflies Fly At The Paul Smith's VIC Butterfly House

Out in the Adirondack wilds, we see plenty of butterflies: one here, one there, and on sunny days sometimes just about everywhere. To learn about their lives and lore, and to see a variety up close, there's no better idea than to visit the Butterfly House. It's in Paul Smith's, at the Visitor Interpretive Center run by Paul Smith's College, right next door. Prepare to be amazed!  
A Taste Of Oak: Adirondack Coopers Bring Flavor To Regional Whiskey

Along a country road and down a long gravel driveway, Adirondack coopers Bob Hockert and Justin Bidelspach make world-class barrels fit for aging fine whiskies. They begin with select white oak boards cut by sawyers to their specifications. In the end, after much shaving, joining, charring, assembling, and the pressing on of hoops, a barrel is born---handsome, shapely, supremely practical, and prized by a rapidly expanding array of regional distillers. Learn more by visiting www.usbarrel.com.
Kids As Pets: Why Your Next 'Dog' Might Be A Goat

In the Adirondacks, people love their pets. Some of them---the pets, that is---weigh two hundred pounds or more and thrive on pine needles, poison-ivy, and other delicacies you can't buy at the supermarket. Ask these animals to sit up like trained dogs, and they'll say Naaaaaaaaaaaa. Yes, goats! For many of us, they are the pet of choice, and some earn livings or parts of livings raising and milking them, too. Learn more about Asgaard Farm & Dairy by visiting www.asgaardfarm.com.
The Adirondack Mountain Village Of Saranac Lake Remembers Its Curative Past

Most of us have heard William Faulkner's famous line about the past not being dead. His wisdom is nowhere more apparent than in the Adirondack Mountain village of Saranac Lake. Here, from the 1880s to the 1950s and a little bit beyond, tuberculosis patients arrived from near and far to rest on porches, breathe crisp pine-scented mountain air, and get well or die trying. Antibiotic therapy eventually put the village's sanitariums and cure cottages out of business. Still, in architecture, memory, story, and a heart-breaking poem penned by a brilliant young woman who didn't live to see it published, the village's rich past remains alive. Learn more about the work of Historic Saranac Lake by visiting www.historicsaranaclake.org.
Catch Our Drift: Why Adirondackers Love Winter, Sort OfDo we in the Adirondacks love snow and cold? Do we hate them? Hear dyed-in-the-wool locals speak their minds about our long, cold, crystalline season.Fifty Beds, Two Lakes, And An Otter: Bartlett's Hotel In Its Heyday, 1854-1884The late nineteenth century might be called the Golden Age of Adirondack Hotels. Among the humble and the grand, one establishment stands out above all the others for its character and for its characters: Virgil and Caroline Bartlett's Sportsmen's Home, which had its heyday from 1854 to 1884. "Bartlett's," as the place was often called, stood at the downstream end of the Bartlett Carry between the Upper and Middle Saranac Lakes. Fran Yardley, a professional storyteller and author, has lived near the remote site of the hotel for more than forty years. She's our guide as Curiously Adirondack takes a look at a place renowned for its warm welcomes, delicious meals, cozy rooms, and pet otter. Be sure to watch for Fran's upcoming book FINDING TRUE NORTH: A History of One Small Corner of the Adirondacks releasing July 1, 2018. Sign up for her monthly newsletter by clicking here.     Adirondack Exercise ClubHardy Adirondack Mountain folk chant 1-2-3-4 as we prepare to stay warm during cold, snowy winters that can last half the year or more. It's all about firewood: felling it, sawing it to length, hauling it out of the woods, splitting it, moving it, stacking it, moving it again a time or two, and finally feeding it to hungry woodstoves. Yes, an unlucky few of us twirl thermostats, summon central heat, and hand over hard-earned cash to the oil and gas industry, but the rest of us maintain our trim figures, keep strong, and get free cardiovascular exercise as we work out at the most popular exercise club in the region.Intervale Lowlands: Biologist Larry Master Re-Wilds 135 Acres Near Lake PlacidIn 2009, biologist Larry Master and his then-wife, Nancy, bought 135 acres of woods, fields, flowing water, and floodplain near Lake Placid in the Adirondack Mountains. Their mission: to make the property sing with songbirds, to convert its mowed fields to meadows full of native plants and animals, and to identify and monitor its wildlife in an era of rapid climate change. They decided to call the place, tucked in an exquisite river valley between ranges of mountains, Intervale Lowlands.What Does The Moose Say?There are spelling bees. There are trivia contests. There are athletic games and lumberjack competitions. But have you ever seen and heard a moose-calling contest? The scene is wild, competitors are fierce, and it's all in good fun. Learn more about the Great Adirondack Moose Festival by visiting www.indian-lake.com.Dirt, Food, And Friends: Fledging Crow Farm Celebrates The HarvestIn Keeseville, on the eastern edge of upstate New York's Adirondack Mountains, a new-fangled subscription farm called Fledging Crow grows food the old fashioned way: with lots of elbow grease, lots of help from neighbors, and no artificial fertilizers or pesticides. Every year, the farmers celebrate their harvest and the community of life that made it possible by throwing a giant party, a sort of mini-Woodstock in the fields. It's called CrowFest. Join Curiously Adirondack as we mix and mingle with a curious cast of characters who tell the story of Fledging Crow Farm and who and what make it work.Asleep Beneath The Sod: Saranac Lake's Historic Pine Ridge Cemetery
Saranac Lake's Pine Ridge Cemetery sprawls over a sandy hillside in the heart of the village. In it lie the last remains of the village's first settlers, and keeping them company are hundreds of others, some well known and some not, who followed them across the great divide. Join Curiously Adirondack in a ramble through the cemetery with the best of all possible guides: Natalie Leduc, one of the village's grand dames, a former Winter Carnival queen who looks after the cemetery and, when her rich and adventurous life is done, aims to be buried there.
Slimed! Adirondack Kids Love Amphibians

Adirondack kids can't resist slimy things that hop and crawl. Join three warm-blooded young naturalists as they hunt for frogs, toads, and salamanders. Don't think amphibians are cool? Maybe we can change your mind.

If you made it this far, perhaps you're interested. Great! And thank you.
Fundraising is tricky business. Let's be honest. Who enjoys asking for money? Still, ask we must--- because we believe in the value of Curiously Adirondack. Judging by the positive feedback we've received over the years, we know our storytelling resonates. So we hope you'll join us and find that supporting Curiously Adirondack is a little less painful than paying your monthly cable bill. Hundreds of channel choices are great. Yet not one of those channels highlights the Adirondacks like we do.
We're proud that our supporters always know where their money is going. We're just a couple of family guys trying to make a living, doing what we do best. Support of any sort means the world to us. Thank you!
When my wife Holly and I launched Josh Clement Productions two and a half years ago we did so with two goals in mind: to tell human-interest stories that focus on those who live, work, and play in the Adirondacks and to use the business and production skills we've gathered over the years to earn a dollar. Although not without its challenges, we've managed to thrive.
We've helped numerous institutions, organizations, and businesses reach video and web marketing goals. For that we are proud. Yet for us, all roads lead back to Curiously Adirondack. The series has generated excitement. The numbers are there to prove it. People ask, "When can we see the next episode of Curiously Adirondack?" Or they’ll say, "I've got the perfect story idea for you guys. It would make a great Curiously Adirondack!" I love that! The enthusiasm leaves me smiling . I know we're onto something special.
Which leads to the main point I wanted to make. Why does Curiously Adirondack work? Why is it essential to the success of Josh Clement Productions? The answer leads to my collaborator, my friend and neighbor, Ed Kanze. Putting together Curiously Adirondack is hard work. I could not do it alone. One needs only to look at the credits of any quality video production to realize what makes them shine. Ed Kanze is a seasoned storyteller, author, photographer, editor, and more. He is quick to praise what I bring to the table. For that I am most appreciative. Well, it goes both ways. I’m thrilled to be in his corner.
Ed and I will remain forever Curiously Adirondack! How about you?

story:
The Concept

If you watched our pitch video, you already know this information verbatim, but in case you skipped that:

Who Are You’s first season focuses on Tyler West, an investigative journalist whose life has been marred by unspeakable tragedy. His former home of Oakford, Georgia, was the hunting ground of a serial killer in his preteen years and his mother, Emily, was that killer’s final victim. His father, Victor, has been in prison for over a decade, supposedly having been the killer. When Tyler returns home to prove his father’s innocence after being sent away to survive the foster care system, he must deal with some old faces, both friendly and not so much. His theory is also bolstered by the emergence of a new, copycat serial killer. Nick Bradshaw will be directing the episode based on a teleplay by Andy Epsilantis, Joseph A. Reinhard, and Nick Pataky and a story by Andy Epsilantis and Benjamin Murray.

 

Breakdown

We have a talented cast, a thrilling script, some cool locations, and an imaginative director and crew on board. What we need is to secure this final piece of the puzzle – our funding – so we can begin shooting in earnest. The amount we estimate we need in order to do that is $25,000 (USD), broken down as follows:

  1. Cast and Crew: We need to pay everybody who's taking off work during our 13 days of production. We also have to cover their travel to Baltimore and their lodging expenses while they're here.
  2. Production Costs: This means the rental cost of lighting equipment and camera equipment; purchasing hard drives, wardrobe, and whatever's needed for set design; covering craft food services; and any other incidentals that may come up.
  3. Post-Production Costs: Editing, sound mixing, etc.
  4. Indiegogo and Perks: We have to buy all the swag that you guys earned by donating to our cause. Indiegogo also takes a sliver of whatever we raise off the top.

 

About the Cast

 


Glenn Ghirardi (Tyler West) is an actor and producer, who has appeared in Columbia Pictures' Here Comes the Boom and That's My Boy. He is also well-versed in theatre, playing Melchior in Spring Awakening, James Keller in The Miracle Worker, and Tybalt in Romeo and Juliet. His production of Spring Awakening sold out.

 

Jessica Sharples (Rachel Simms) holds a Bachelor's of Fine Arts from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. She is an actress and model, who has appeared in Law & Order: Special Victims Unit as well as commercials for Lumeris Laser Hair Removal and Marriott Hotels.

 

Gary Napoli (Geoff Harrison) has the widest ranging television background among the cast. He has done comedic work for Comedy Central; soap opera work for CBS's As the World Turns; and, most notably, dramatic work for HBO, starring as Robert Durst in the Emmy Award-winning true crime miniseries The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst.

 

Daniel Braswell (Victor West) is a retired Naval Officer, who commanded a helicopter squadron deployed to Europe, Africa, and the Middle East, with an MBA from the University of Maryland. He frequently works with the State Department and the Department of Defense as a roleplayer for military training exercises. He has also appeared in film and TV and on the stage.

 

Chris Jehnert (Alec Dixon) has appeared in The Michael J. Fox Show on NBC and done a lot of music-based work, such as touring with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra as part of a production of Hairspray and working with director Jorma Taccone of The Lonely Island and Saturday Night Live's Ana Gasteyer on the music video "One Mint Julep." He also starred for two seasons in Amazon's Disposable Teens, which earned a Streamy Award nomination in 2016 for Best Indie Web Series.

 

Amy Connerley (Valerie Harrison) has experience in television, film, and theatre, but is best known for her dancing. She has 15 years' worth of experience in tap, ballet, and contemporary, as well as a decade's knowledge of hip-hop.

 

Matt Ashby (Ian Palmer) is a theatre actor who has appeared as Prior in Angels in America and Rocky in The Rocky Horror Picture Show. He studied at the Circle in the Square Theater School on Broadway. This year, he has already starred in two short films – Words of a Son and Remade.

 

Rick Jermain (Mack Willis) has appeared in National Geographic Channel's American Genius and the hit 2016 independent thriller A Clean Exit. Furthermore, he just completed his directorial debut – a short film titled More Red – as part of Baltimore's 48 Hour Film Project for 2018.

 

Lyon Beckwith (Benny Hart) immersed himself in several diverse career endeavors from modeling to dancing to Mixed Martial Arts, yet settled on his passion for acting. Most recently, he appeared opposite Gerard Butler and 50 Cent in STX Films' Den of Thieves.

 

Dennis P. Marburger (Chuck Simms) has worked with both Sirens Media and Story House Productions on a multitude of projects for Investigation Discovery. He can also be seen in Netflix's House of Cards.

 

About the Creative Team

 

Nick Bradshaw (Executive Producer, Director) started shooting short films when he was 8-years-old, and since then, has shot and/or worked on 30+ shorts, features, and television shoots. He has worked independently, as well as professionally, in film, television, and theatre since he was about 15, most recently for The Late Show with Stephen Colbert and on a pilot that premiered at the Dances with Films Film Festival in Los Angeles, California. Nick is classically trained in theatre writing, directing, and management; and is gearing up to shoot his feature directorial debut, Dr. Gypsy, in the summer of 2019. He is currently a college student double majoring in Cinema, Television, and Emerging Media with a concentration in Screenwriting, and Theatre Arts with a concentration in Directing at Marymount Manhattan College, while also serving as the owner and head operator of Bay One Pictures, a small, New York Tri-State Area based studio.

 

Andy Epsilantis (Creator, Executive Producer, Head Writer) is currently a senior at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County double majoring in Cinematic Arts and Political Science. In 2017, he traveled to Nashville to shoot a sitcom pilot titled It's Complicated that he had been developing with his producing partner, Joseph A. Reinhard, since late 2011. He most recently finished a short film for school called Skin, which is awaiting a response from the Atlanta Horror Film Festival. Above, he and frequent collaborator Rick Jermain are on set of their boxing film We All Have Demons, setting up for the climax. Andy will also reteam with Nick next year as the production coordinator on Dr. Gypsy.

 

Joseph A. Reinhard (Producer, Writer, Co-Director of Photography), far right, has been studying photography and lighting for a few years. He has been working with Andy since he was 14-years-old and a freshman in high school. Joseph can be seen above assisting Director of Photography Cody Duncum on the pilot shoot for It's Complicated after six years of his and Andy's hard work finally paid off.

 

Nick Pataky (Producer, Writer, Co-Director of Photography) is an actor, writer, and musician, who has been working with his friends Joseph and Andy for several years now. In 2017, he traveled with them to Nashville to shoot their pilot It's Complicated. Nick, center in the photograph above, can be seen helping rehearse and block an important scene with Joseph, stars Rick Jermain and Dean Kostlich, and director Ender Bowen.

 

Julia Dunford (Producer, Story Editor) is currently pursing a Bachelor's of Arts in Digital Media and Video Production from Marymount Manhattan College. In 2017, she served as a production assistant on the aforementioned Dances with Films pilot. She is also working with Nick on Dr. Gypsy as that film's line producer.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate or you already have and you're looking for additional ways to aid our endeavor, here are some other things you can do to help us get Who Are You off the ground:

  1. Like us on Facebook, react to our posts, and share them.
  2. Follow us on Twitter and/or Instagram.
  3. Share this campaign on your own social media profiles using the buttons on the top right.
  4. Email this page to people you think may be interested and want to know more about the project or who may be able to donate.
  5. Talk about the project in real life with your friends, your family, and even that possible sociopath you know!
story_txt:
The ConceptIf you watched our pitch video, you already know this information verbatim, but in case you skipped that:Who Are You’s first season focuses on Tyler West, an investigative journalist whose life has been marred by unspeakable tragedy. His former home of Oakford, Georgia, was the hunting ground of a serial killer in his preteen years and his mother, Emily, was that killer’s final victim. His father, Victor, has been in prison for over a decade, supposedly having been the killer. When Tyler returns home to prove his father’s innocence after being sent away to survive the foster care system, he must deal with some old faces, both friendly and not so much. His theory is also bolstered by the emergence of a new, copycat serial killer. Nick Bradshaw will be directing the episode based on a teleplay by Andy Epsilantis, Joseph A. Reinhard, and Nick Pataky and a story by Andy Epsilantis and Benjamin Murray. BreakdownWe have a talented cast, a thrilling script, some cool locations, and an imaginative director and crew on board. What we need is to secure this final piece of the puzzle – our funding – so we can begin shooting in earnest. The amount we estimate we need in order to do that is $25,000 (USD), broken down as follows:

Cast and Crew: We need to pay everybody who's taking off work during our 13 days of production. We also have to cover their travel to Baltimore and their lodging expenses while they're here.

Production Costs: This means the rental cost of lighting equipment and camera equipment; purchasing hard drives, wardrobe, and whatever's needed for set design; covering craft food services; and any other incidentals that may come up.

Post-Production Costs: Editing, sound mixing, etc.

Indiegogo and Perks: We have to buy all the swag that you guys earned by donating to our cause. Indiegogo also takes a sliver of whatever we raise off the top.
 About the Cast Glenn Ghirardi (Tyler West) is an actor and producer, who has appeared in Columbia Pictures' Here Comes the Boom and That's My Boy. He is also well-versed in theatre, playing Melchior in Spring Awakening, James Keller in The Miracle Worker, and Tybalt in Romeo and Juliet. His production of Spring Awakening sold out. Jessica Sharples (Rachel Simms) holds a Bachelor's of Fine Arts from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. She is an actress and model, who has appeared in Law & Order: Special Victims Unit as well as commercials for Lumeris Laser Hair Removal and Marriott Hotels. Gary Napoli (Geoff Harrison) has the widest ranging television background among the cast. He has done comedic work for Comedy Central; soap opera work for CBS's As the World Turns; and, most notably, dramatic work for HBO, starring as Robert Durst in the Emmy Award-winning true crime miniseries The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst. Daniel Braswell (Victor West) is a retired Naval Officer, who commanded a helicopter squadron deployed to Europe, Africa, and the Middle East, with an MBA from the University of Maryland. He frequently works with the State Department and the Department of Defense as a roleplayer for military training exercises. He has also appeared in film and TV and on the stage. Chris Jehnert (Alec Dixon) has appeared in The Michael J. Fox Show on NBC and done a lot of music-based work, such as touring with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra as part of a production of Hairspray and working with director Jorma Taccone of The Lonely Island and Saturday Night Live's Ana Gasteyer on the music video "One Mint Julep." He also starred for two seasons in Amazon's Disposable Teens, which earned a Streamy Award nomination in 2016 for Best Indie Web Series. Amy Connerley (Valerie Harrison) has experience in television, film, and theatre, but is best known for her dancing. She has 15 years' worth of experience in tap, ballet, and contemporary, as well as a decade's knowledge of hip-hop. Matt Ashby (Ian Palmer) is a theatre actor who has appeared as Prior in Angels in America and Rocky in The Rocky Horror Picture Show. He studied at the Circle in the Square Theater School on Broadway. This year, he has already starred in two short films – Words of a Son and Remade. Rick Jermain (Mack Willis) has appeared in National Geographic Channel's American Genius and the hit 2016 independent thriller A Clean Exit. Furthermore, he just completed his directorial debut – a short film titled More Red – as part of Baltimore's 48 Hour Film Project for 2018. Lyon Beckwith (Benny Hart) immersed himself in several diverse career endeavors from modeling to dancing to Mixed Martial Arts, yet settled on his passion for acting. Most recently, he appeared opposite Gerard Butler and 50 Cent in STX Films' Den of Thieves. Dennis P. Marburger (Chuck Simms) has worked with both Sirens Media and Story House Productions on a multitude of projects for Investigation Discovery. He can also be seen in Netflix's House of Cards. About the Creative Team Nick Bradshaw (Executive Producer, Director) started shooting short films when he was 8-years-old, and since then, has shot and/or worked on 30+ shorts, features, and television shoots. He has worked independently, as well as professionally, in film, television, and theatre since he was about 15, most recently for The Late Show with Stephen Colbert and on a pilot that premiered at the Dances with Films Film Festival in Los Angeles, California. Nick is classically trained in theatre writing, directing, and management; and is gearing up to shoot his feature directorial debut, Dr. Gypsy, in the summer of 2019. He is currently a college student double majoring in Cinema, Television, and Emerging Media with a concentration in Screenwriting, and Theatre Arts with a concentration in Directing at Marymount Manhattan College, while also serving as the owner and head operator of Bay One Pictures, a small, New York Tri-State Area based studio. Andy Epsilantis (Creator, Executive Producer, Head Writer) is currently a senior at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County double majoring in Cinematic Arts and Political Science. In 2017, he traveled to Nashville to shoot a sitcom pilot titled It's Complicated that he had been developing with his producing partner, Joseph A. Reinhard, since late 2011. He most recently finished a short film for school called Skin, which is awaiting a response from the Atlanta Horror Film Festival. Above, he and frequent collaborator Rick Jermain are on set of their boxing film We All Have Demons, setting up for the climax. Andy will also reteam with Nick next year as the production coordinator on Dr. Gypsy. Joseph A. Reinhard (Producer, Writer, Co-Director of Photography), far right, has been studying photography and lighting for a few years. He has been working with Andy since he was 14-years-old and a freshman in high school. Joseph can be seen above assisting Director of Photography Cody Duncum on the pilot shoot for It's Complicated after six years of his and Andy's hard work finally paid off. Nick Pataky (Producer, Writer, Co-Director of Photography) is an actor, writer, and musician, who has been working with his friends Joseph and Andy for several years now. In 2017, he traveled with them to Nashville to shoot their pilot It's Complicated. Nick, center in the photograph above, can be seen helping rehearse and block an important scene with Joseph, stars Rick Jermain and Dean Kostlich, and director Ender Bowen. Julia Dunford (Producer, Story Editor) is currently pursing a Bachelor's of Arts in Digital Media and Video Production from Marymount Manhattan College. In 2017, she served as a production assistant on the aforementioned Dances with Films pilot. She is also working with Nick on Dr. Gypsy as that film's line producer. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate or you already have and you're looking for additional ways to aid our endeavor, here are some other things you can do to help us get Who Are You off the ground:
Like us on Facebook, react to our posts, and share them.
Follow us on Twitter and/or Instagram.
Share this campaign on your own social media profiles using the buttons on the top right.
Email this page to people you think may be interested and want to know more about the project or who may be able to donate.

story:
In Damaged Goods, you'll meet the voluptuous family members in all their beauty, piety, and defiance and watch them strategize over their inheritance. Learn how wills in the Big Easy can be changed on a dime.

A dark sway rains over the monied rich in this New Orleans world of Damaged Goods. Each family member pursues a calling in real estate or art that has morphed into an obsession. The quest propels each to confront evil, out with the estate, or die in the process.

Damaged Goods exposes rich, bizarre Southern characters caught in a dangerous pursuit that causes them to act in strange, eccentric and transformed ways to get money and sex.

In Damaged Goods, you'll meet the New Orleans top drawer, in all their defiant and jaded sensuality. The people the great Louisiana hotels were built for, the lobbies showcasing the Mississippi River, the silver service steaming with jasmine tea, the harpist strumming the Clair de Lune. Peer behind the lace curtains into their hurtful world of betrayal and defiance.

In Damaged Goods, you'll meet the New Orleans top drawer, in all their defiant and jaded sensuality. story:
What we're about...

We are a group of creatives with a passion for representation and connecting people. "Validated" humanizes the struggles many people (especially minorities)  go through. But we approach those issues from a comedic lens to draw our audience in. You might laugh. You might cry. You may learn about a perspective that's different from your own -- or you may identify with the story in a very visceral way. At our highest ambition, we're just starting conversations between people by highlighting injustices, commenting on social issues, emphasizing the importance of inclusion, and making you laugh in the process. 

If you take anything away from our show, we hope it's an appreciation for others, no matter what their background, ethicity, gender, sexual orentation, religion, or any lables on your checklist. Because when it comes down to it, Twitter should not be the only reason you care about a cause. 

 

What We Need:

We'd love to take an iPhone out and shoot on the streets of our city, but to do these stories justice, we may need a little more than that..

Our goal is $3,000.

Every bit of funding goes to 2 simple aspects of filmmaking:

Our crew, who's passion to tell these stories, and talent to make them look impeccable, deserve all our praise (and a good meal on set).

Our locations. We'd love to not only highlight stories that need to be told, but businesess and social movements that are pushing for equality as well. By giving them a platform to be seen for their own missions, we might help bridge the gap. So by filming in places specific to our city, Atlanta, GA, which has been plagued by gentrification and displacement, we hope to help small businesses be seen & heard, and save some from being replaced.

 

THAT'S IT! We'll handle the rest, as filmmakers always find a way to do so!

story:
Mission

Warehouse TV is a nonprofit organization that provides the disabled community the visibility and opportunity they are not given in the film industry by giving them a space to build their experience, grow their professional networks, and hopefully produce award-winning shows to further bolster their names in the industry.

 

Problem & Solution

The film industry isn’t very accessible because people who fund and operate productions prefer work within guarantees. But how can disabled people provide guarantees without proof? We circumvent this problem by providing production resources for filming such as equipment, studio space, a platform to broadcast, et cetra. While we will require the majority of our crews be disabled, we embrace productions that aim to integrate professionals of all types

It doesn't end at our channel, either. Not only do we aim to cultivate people’s experiences, we also aim to increase visibility by entering our shows into various competitions annually.

 

Theory of Change

The industry operates mainly by networking, so our solution will produce two positive outcomes: First, in giving disabled people the opportunity to work with other professionals, their career network grows. And second, the disabled person garners enough hours and experience to join unions. The more disabled people that succeed, the more visible they are to the industry, and the more accessible the industry will become.

 

Reasons to Donate

  • Right here's where you don't just talk about disability and diversity in film, you DO something about it!
  • We are committed to keeping this studio up and running for people to have access to. If we don't make our fundraising goal we will have to reduce the amount of people we can help, meaning we will have smaller crews and fewer shows.
  • And we've got some great perks!

 

What we do with your money...

We built Warehouse TV as a nonprofit organization so that you can trust that every cent will be spent on our mission and creating the best possible content that will raise the bar for everyone. We've budgeted for two categories: General Operation and Show Budgets. 


General Operation: 

  • Studio Space
  • Lights & Cameras
  • Office Supplies
  • Wi-Fi & Network
  • Digital & Physical Storage
  • Website Hosting

Show Budget:

  • Crew Stipends
  • Talent Stipends
  • Set Decoration
  • Craft Services
  • Post Production Costs

 

Here's a sneak peek at some of

the shows we have lined up!
